title: Shendrones Tweaker 180 Lightbar, Antenna Mount & HS1177 Mount

description.text:
There are a few Shendrones Tweaker 180 light mounts, but none that are 50mm across to permit 3 LEDs from a 60LED/m strip to fit cleanly.  So I knocked this up.  You might want to adjust the depth of the cubes in the (horrible, terrible) SCAD file so the bar doesn't overhang the back of the frame by a mm or so, but as provided it leaves the most room for the ESC on the rear arms.
You may also need to adjust the standoff diameter if you aren't using the stock gold 5mm ones - I gave a half-mm allowance over the 5mm pins I used and it's still a moderately tight fit.  There are constants declared that define the inner dimension and outer dimension between the posts, and commented out truth bars that can help you make sure you're adjusting things the right way before going to print it.
Updated 2015-10-05 to put vias for zip ties, bring the bar back to be more flush with the back of the quad's frame, and provide a passageway for the rear ESCs power connectors so they aren't quite so tight on 18xx class motors.  Print with support to keep the raft face hidden, or flip 180 and print that way if your printer produces clean raft separation.
Updated 2015-10-07 to add a second lightbar for the front.  It should fit under a board cam and not interfere with the lower mounting nuts, while still being wide enough for 3 LEDs.  It's a twin of the rear lightbar, and if you wanted you could use the front file for both front and rear.
Updated 2015-10-24 to add a dual antenna mounting solution.  It's designed for the standard 1/8" Du-bro style antenna tubes, drill it out per usual for printed parts.
Updated 2015-12-07 to add a HS1177 (aka Foxeer XAT600M DC5V-22V 600tvl Sony Super HAD CCD FPV Camera) mount.  The standard one just screws in to the frame using a M3x8 screw & nut, the mk2 also aligns over the front standoffs.  Note, they'll both need longer screws to tap in to the camera itself - the ones I'm using are 2.3x6mm.  The camera is a tight fit, but it does eventually get in there.  Currently untested - but I was getting slop in the stock metal bracket, so here we are.
Drill out the holes as per any printed object meeting a non-printed object and go to town.

author: Garyb10688

description.text:
This is a remix of dalpek's Bat Signal to incorporate a small LED push button light in the end.  I utilized the inner battery chamber of the motorcycle LED keychain flashlight to create the electronics section and swapped out the bat signal itself with another one that was a little bigger and better proportioned.
UPDATE 6/5/2016: Added generic signal sketchup file to allow people to create their own base.  Modify the group that is the disk inside the base and then use the STL plugin to export both groups to a single stl.  Clean with NetFabb after export to finish cleaning it up prior to slicing.

Assemble Flashlight
  • Put 5mm LED leads through holes in battery holder with the longer positive lead toward the bottom of the chamber.
  • Use a small flat head screw driver to force it into slot that leads to the bottom of the chamber.
  • Clip positive lead just short of hole on bottom of chamber, and negative lead just short of the other end of the chamber.
  • Put in CR2032 battery positive side down in between the two LED leads.
  • Add battery ring between battery and negative lead to prevent unwanted activation of LED.
  • Align slot in battery button with the negative LED lead and snap into place.
    • Assemble Bat Signal
  • Clean up hole for protruding LED to slide into the main unit.
  • Test fit. The flashlight will be very snug and may require a little sanding in order to fit into slot.
  • Once assembly is possible, add a little super glue to slotted area of base unit and slide in LED flashlight and let dry.
    • Battery Replacement
  • Use a paper clip to push through small hole on bottom of flashlight to pop the battery button out of it's place.

description.text:
Joint parts for a mini table. Using wood rods as frames, cardboard as tabletop.
I designed this model for bicycle trips. (lightweight and easy to carry) I uploaded 2 series, diameter 3/8inch(approximate as 9.6mm) and 8.0mm.
Check your wood rod's diameter ( and 3D printer accuracy ) by tester_9.6mm.stl or tester_8.0mm.stl. All models can be printed without supports. Wood rod in the photo is 300mm in length, 8mm in diameter (Easy to buy in Japan). Search 3/8"x12" wooden dowel at amazon.com. Instruction:
  • Download and print tester_9.6mm.stl for 3/8" wood rods, or tester_8.0mm.stl for 8mm wood rods.
  • Determine wood rod's diameter by the tester.
  • Download corresponding zip file, print and assemble!
    • [Japanese]
    8mm径の丸棒で小さな三角テーブルを組み立てるためのジョイントです。天板にはダンボールを使います。
    自転車旅行で使うために設計しました。(軽量、パニアバッグ内で場所を取らない) 寸法を正確に合わせる必要があるので、tester_8.0mm.stl を出力して実際のサイズを確認して下さい。tester_9.6mm.stl は米国向けの3/8インチ径用です。 全てのパーツはサポートなしで印刷できます。 作成手順:
  • ホームセンターで売っている8mmx900mmの丸棒(1本100～200円)を2本買ってきて、30cmずつに切断します。キッチンばさみで周囲に切れ目を入れれば手で折れます。
  • "tester_8.0mm.stl"をダウンロードして出力し、対応するサイズを確認します。(ほどよく固定されるサイズを探す)
  • 確認したサイズの名前が付いているZIPファイルをダウンロードして出力し、組み立てます。

description.text: A collaboration with +bradkenney Was doing some experimentation with the Makerlele body to see the effect of making it more solid. This version of the body features an elliptical cavity that narrows to the front hole and solid construction. This was designed to be printed at 100% infill and has incredibly thick walls. As a result, talking into the front blasts your voice back into your face! In hindsight, the body cavity has a somewhat parabolic shape, so I shouldn't be all too surprised. Has a great sweet spot for drumming on the back right at the edge of the internal chamber nearest the bridge. I'll certainly print all future drums at 100% infil

The strummed sound was nowhere near as great as talking into the soundhole was.  Still, a solid infill body showed incredible reflective properties... meaning the next obvious step to try is a properly parabolic resonance chamber with the focal point at the Z-level of the strings.

title: Hollow filament spool with DVD's for M3D / Micro 3D printer (made with 2 CD/DVD)

description.text:
Work in Progress! Those who have a M3D (I have one, but it is not working, will be returned for repairs) may have the problen that they want to use own / other filament than the M3D-Stock. No problem, but if they want to use it in the internal compartment under the printbed... Well... Where to get spools and not buying from M3D LLC? Simple! Make your own!
The diameter of those spools was measured to be 120mm. Hm... Where did i saw this size and form last? RIGHT! CD's and DVD's! The same diameter! So i just whipped up some sort of spool-core to add a CD on top and at the bottom, some glue and presto! Things i tryed to incorporate:
  • A large enough space to glue the center to the CD's: a rim of 0.5cm should suffice
  • both filamentsizes of 1.75mm (M3D-Diameter) and 3.0mm have 4 holes each to "start" the winding
  • Be printable with low amount of filament, but be stury: 2mm walls & staged design
  • lowest winding-diameter of filament > 40mm due to breaking-prone PLA if wound smaller

Printer:

M3D

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Low. Used 0.2mm

Not needed

title: Sells Mendel improved X Carriage for EckerTech Hot End

description.text:
All of the plastic parts required to convert a standard Sells Mendel to an EckerTech all metal Hot End. The EckerTech all metal hot end is available at http://www.eckertech.com/mendel-hot-end/ As well as adapting the extruder block to fit our hot end we made some improvements to the carriage:
  • We re-positioned the lower carriage rear bearing mounts after finding out that they were misaligned in the original files?!?
  • We replaced the original lower carriage tower with a flat printed independent unit which is much stronger.
  • We added belt alignment notches to the tower and blocks to the clamps to hold the belt in proper vertical position while clamping it tight. Eliminates the fiddly part of maintaining vertical alignment of the belt while you tighten it into place.
  • We adapted the upper carriage to fit our clip in eckstruder.
  • We covered the top gear side of upper carriage to better direct the airflow over the heatsink.
  • We updated the eckstruder to the new version wire capture model with spiral wrap tubing.
  • We front mounted the M3X25mm hot end extension locking bolts for easy access.
  • We notched the eckstruder base to provide a clip in attachment for the fan housing.
  • We counter bored the upper carriage to extend the heatsink mounting bolts for attachment to the heatsink.
  • We added nut captures to the outer clamping bolts on the lower carriage for easier tension adjustments of the bearings, as well as counter bored the bearing bolt holes to provide better clearance for the heatsink.
    • We also added spiral wrap tubing adaptors to clean up the wiring.
The instructions for putting this conversion kit together are be available here http://forum.eckertech.com/viewforum.php?f=21.

Text_Rotate = 0

If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays See http://joesmakerbot.blogspot.com/2013/06/creating-test-print-object.html for more information See the annotated picture for details:
A. The organic area just looks pretty and shows how well your printer can print details like this.
B. The arms of the 3 each extend at different angles to test overhang. The top one extends at 60 degrees which may be a challenge for some to print but a properly calibrated machine should be able to handle it. The middle is at 45 degrees, even a badly calibrated machine should be able to do this, the bottom is 70 degrees, bonus points for making that work but it is expected to fail.
C. The D tests arches. With an arch this big it is likely to fail, but it's a question of how far it gets before failing.
D. The H tests bridging.
E. Each letter in "3DHacker.com" is the minimum safe size for text and 0.1mm higher than the one next to it testing relief and raised printing detail. If printing any less than 0.1mm layer heights it is possible there will not be a difference between too letters. Gaps that develop around the sunken letter can be fixed by reducing the number of shells at the cost of... well, shells.
F. The 3 spikes behind the H should be as tall as the H, however this test is designed to fail. Instead it will show how fine the details can be before your slicer will stop putting them in.
G. The main body and secondary block are joined by a filament diameter tester. If your filament diameter is too low you will not be able to mate the two parts. If it's too high they won't stay mated.
H. When mated relief lettering on the bottom of the print will demonstrate how well this can work, and the trouble that shells can cause for this.
I. On the top side of the second half the top wall demonstrates vertical holes with triangles, squares, on to circle.
J. In the middle is a shape designed to demonstrate how thin, flat organic shapes can turn out sometimes when designed horizontally like the legs of an octopus or a tail. This part may not be fixable simply by dropping shells, it's just one of those quirks to be aware of.
K. The bottom wall is designed as a fail test where the wall is getting increasingly thinner until it's too thin to print, but at what point will your 3D printer stop printing. It's a bit bigger than some tests but it covers a lot.

title: Recess plug for Greg's Wade Reloaded with automatic hotend alignment

description.text: Print is 1mm too tall. I'll fix it later. Update: Scad & stl files for both 3mm and 1.75mm filaments! I switched from a jhead to a stainless steel Prusa hotend, however the new hotend mounts to an aluminum plate that has a slight depression where the hotend doesn't quite screw in all the way. I've taken the recess part from the Greg's Wade Reloaded extruder scad and added a little extruding ring to the recess plug to allow my plate to automatically center on the extruder. The result is (hopefully) no more gap acting as a heat trap, and no more slightly offset hotend plate. The automatic alignment should help to reduce filament feeding resistance and make it faster to assemble the whole thing.

• Check the hole with your filament, If it's too snug, drill it out.

  • Give the top edge a slight taper with a larger drill bit by hand, or just use a small file. You should only need to remove the very edge in case the alignment isn't perfect to your extruder so it won't be able to bind when you're loading filament.
    • Alternatively, don't taper the top at all, and just align the hole with a piece of filament sitting in your hotend when you tighten down the extruder. The main point of this thing is to fill that air gap.

comments.text: Just wanted to say you can buy this piece as a common nylon bit at a hardware store. Conveniently, the nylon bit also has an inner diameter that perfectly fits a piece of PTFE tubing. Only costs 50 cents or so.

description.text:
Important Update 22-08-2016
  • please do not print and try to make the current version of this design! The path that the belts follow are not correctly setup this way, they are not perpendicular.
  • see discussion at RepRap forum:
    http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?344,563301,656013#msg-656013
    • I made the mistake trying to create as much effective build volume within the boundaries of the cube, while not taking into account some basic ground rules for CoreXY.
    My bad... Update 10-07-2015
  • changed Zbottom_belt part for better attachment of the stepper motor
  • some optical changes to some parts
  • updated assembled stl for viewing of current revision
    • Update 10-04-2015
    I have found a simple way to use Optical Endstops and a couple of pieces of a tiewrap to trigger them.
  • part YSlide_Bot_Endstop has been changed to YSlide_Bot_X_Endstop_tiewrap and includes a slot for a piece of tiewrap to be mounted
  • new part YSlide_Bot_Y_Endstop_tiewrap has been added which replaces the YSlide_Top_Bot part, which also has a slot for a piece of tiewrap.
  • new part Y_Endstop_holder has been added to mount a Optical Endstop on the right stepper motor
  • removed Endstop_Holder part which is not used in this design
  • added BOM with prices

Source files can be found here (save a copy to edit parts):
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/10a8f0214fa64912a989ba8d/w/774092f1242a47238ff32759/e/805452aa2f6e4f1a9012b2d3 Some of you may already have seen my 8mm rod parts for the SmartrapCore standard version (thingiverse).
I have been adapting more parts to suit my needs for the experimental version I have designed. Since Smartfriendz released their ALU version and upgraded standard version to Onshape, I have been playing with them while learning Onshape.
The experimental part of this is to see if a design with cheap 13mm square Alu tubes from Hobby King would work for a cheap and easy to assemble SmartrapCore version. While I like the Smartfriendz design very much I found that, for the size of the box, the buildvolume could be a little bigger. I felt the newest itteration lost some width in the X axis. I altered the standard parts to:
  • use 8mm smooth rods
  • use copper self lubricating bushings i.s.o. standard bearings (parts are now simpler in design and need less assembling)
  • make the X axis as wide as possible within the standard alu square tubes of 400mm
  • raise the X/Y axis a little to make the belt path possible on top and as wide as could be
    • I designed the corner braces for the bottom and top. The ones on top have both the steppers and XY_bearings_LR integrated.
    Designing and using these parts, I was able to get a 250mm X axis buildplate size (300mm between the YSlide_L and R minus the 50mm of the Head part). The total build volume is 250x300x300 (XYZ).

Industar 22 50mm is a nice lens with a cool vintage look thanks to its telescopic body.
It can be adapted to SONY NEX family with a M39 ring. However there are two drawbacks :
  • the infinity focusing lock tab is blocked on most adapters (either the adapter has to be filed or the lock has to be unscrewed)
  • the telescopic lens is too long and when stocked back might touch the inner of the camera close to the sensor place...
    • To avoid all this, here is a small M42 to M39 ring specialy designed for the industar 22. It has to be installed on a NEX-M42 adapter:
  • focus to infinty is obtained with the lens fully stacked
  • the focus lock is fully functionnal
  • pulling the lens allows to access to macro capabity (5 cm full frame)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Made of black PLA
Print it up side down (rotation 180° on X)
Once printed, just cut the edge of the inner screw as extra plastic might be present due to a fat first layer... Remove any filament or hair : take care to sensor cleanliness ...

For use in bathrooms that have a 1" square bar, typically turned to show a diamond shape (to shed water). The ends that connect the bar to the wall are typically secured in place and not removable. This design provides an attachment point for common bathroom accessories from the hook end.

The top end will wrap the bar and snap into place, using a small amount of flexibility in the ABS.

Outpost 6 is a building for use in 28mm wargaming. It was inspired in part by the great terrain examples shown on the Maelstrom's Edge web site. Dan Newman's Inkscape to OpenSCAD converter and Greg Frost's bevel extrude were both used in the construction of this model; thanks guys! I think it should all be printable, and I look forward to seeing some prints! Oct. 4, 2015:
  • Updated main building roof tiles; they weren't going to print at 0.15mm layers for me (using Simplify3D). This new design looks like it will print.
  • Adjusted angle of little fixture above windows to possibly help with printing (without supports). Thinned walls on annex to save some plastic.
    • Oct. 21, 2015:
  • Made the tower somewhat taller, leaves more room for models on the roof and is more aesthetically pleasing.
  • Rebuilt the complete and exploded views with new tower.
  • Added an "open" tower. This is purely an optional component for those interested in being able to use the interior of the tower for cover.

Door and ladder shapes were created as shapes in Inkscape and converted to polygons with Dan's converter. Greg's bevel extrude was used to bevel the extrusions (obviously) to make them look nicer.
From there it's all OpenSCAD. I know, crazy. I have a better time working in OpenSCAD than Blender or similar, which I really only use for cleaning things up when making these sorts of highly structured models.

title: CHIPbag™ - Customizable Case for NTC's CHIP

description.text:
CHIPbag is a customizeable case for Next Thing Co's C.H.I.P.. Options in Customizer, or by downloading the attached OpenSCAD file, include: Snap case, Standard or Low-Profile design
Openings for headers
Opening for battery connector
Screw mounts added to sides
Bitbeam added to sides or back
Building bricks added to sides or back With my printer, the board fits snugly in the case with the given dimensions, and cannot be shaken out. I haven't made prints with all of the options yet and still have some tweaking to do (particularly to the gridbeam spacing). Expect updates over the next couple of days. Some options will require supports. Your best options right now are the CHIPbag Snap and the CHIPbag Snap with Bitbeam, for which I've attached STL files. I'm still making lots of changes to the OpenSCAD file, so expect things to not always work correctly. There are some variables which do not yet do anything at all. I'll be posting updates to the CHIPbag and my experiments with the CHIP at Applefritter and on the CHIP forum. This project uses the BitBeam and Universal brick builder modules.

title: Walkera QR X350 Pro Landing Skids
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a landing skid for the Walkera QR X350 Pro. I find that the long flat skid is more stable than the stock 4 points landing.
Each full skid weighs 1.2 ounces if printed at 10%.
The ends of the stock rubber feet are stuffed into the skid mounts to secure them to the drone.
The skid mounts were remixed from pLaStIcSpIdEr's leg extensions (located here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:723492) and cut so they were not too long. You will have to print 4 of them and glue them into the ends of the skids. V3 is the full solid skid. I have a Flash Forge Dreamer so it was a tight squeeze on my build plate. V4 is the skid cut in half. Easier to print on smaller build plates. You will have to print both pieces and glue them together. V5 is the skid cut in half with holes in them to put screws through for extra security. Easier to print on smaller build plates. The holes are big enough to accommodate M3 screws and nuts. This one will make sure that the pieces do not come apart in flight or in a crash.

NOTE: Don't download this thing unless you just want to test how the 3D QR tag prints. If that is what you want to do I suggest the mirrored files. Otherwise to turn your QR tags into 3D QR tags just follow the instructions below and read the recommendation in the comments. **Back to the original programming***** I saw the latest post on the ThingiTag http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8174 and wanted to figure out how to make the QR code printable. Did a quick search and found the 2D Image to STL Converter http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:66115. and Voila!!! 3D ThingiTag. So this is not an original but rather a set of instructions. The QR code i tried this with is for my DryErase Bright Crayon Holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:72880 I haven't printed this yet to see how it comes out but when I do I will post the picture and test that when you scan it it takes you to the right page. Update: I've now printed several 3D Thingi Tags and they print fine. One key step as mentioned in the comments is to enable the BW Threshold when turning the image to STL.
Mirroring the image before turning it into an STL will make a stamp for the Tag and ease the process of making many of the same tags.

• Go to thing page
  • Go to the bottom right of the page and click on the Print Tag button under the Give a Shout Out
  • Capture the QR tag with any screen capture software (I used the sniping tool in windows)
  • Download the 2D Image to STL converter
  • Open the QR Code with the converter and let it do its thing.
  • Hit the "Create STL" button in the converter software
  • Open STL in RepG or Makerware to check it was created correctly.

comments.text: sadly, QR codes are rather picky, they require a white border and the non black lines to be white, but the black lines can be any color, so unless there were to be 2 prints, one which is the colored "black lines" and another to slide over the top that is white, im not sure this concept will work.
comments.author: Hopelost9

comments.text: As a stamp it should work.  Print the mirror of the QR code and use it as a stamp to tag our stuff instead of printing it over and over.
comments.author: Hopelost9

comments.text: For a cleaner print, turn on the "Enable B/W Threshold" feature.  :)
comments.author: BloodBlight

comments.text: Thanks, I saw that feature and printed a few samples and will post results when I can. This process definitely works to create the QR code stl but I haven't been able to scan any of them yet.

I made this 9-sided box using the Grasshopper add-on to Rhino3D. Grasshopper is a parametric modeling package and thus allows all the parameters of a model to be changed dynamically.
The screenshot of the Grasshopper control panel shows all the settings for this box. Note that the knob on top of the handle can be either a torus (as shown), a dodecahedron, or a sphere. 
The top fits closely onto the bottom because there is a triangular ridge around the box's top edge that fits into a similar groove in the box top. There are separate parameters that control the size and shape of this ridge. If no top is desired the top edge of the box can be a rounded lip. 
Because Grasshopper has some quirks that can be confusing I am not posting the actual Grasshopper source file here, but will be happy to provide it to anyone who wants it (along with an explanation of how it works.)

Students of math often get confused about what it means to rotate the integral function around the x-axis. This Customizer allows for the generation of 3d models depicting the integral of a square root in various configurations. As this is a work-in-progress, there may still be unknown bugs. Please comment if you encounter any of these bugs.
Note that the Customizer preview is inaccurate, and the final model looks very different than the image in the preview. I also made a short video in POV-Ray using models from this: https://youtu.be/YdLTYTfzx34 For those interested, the files for POV-Ray are included here.

Function Size This is the length of the function, which ends up as the height of the model (in mm). If you would like this at a reasonable size, it is recommended to scale up the model after creating it. Axis/Axis Position The Axis is how far from the axis the function is placed before rotating. If Axis Position is set to below, the function is placed immediately above the axis. If Axis Position is set to above, the top of the function is placed as close to the axis as possible without crossing the axis. Cut Angle This Parameter determines how much of the rotation is shown. If the Cut Angle is set to 360, the function wraps around completely. If set to less, sections of the function are removed. Secondary Function The Customizer can optionally calculate and remove the integral of a secondary function from the main model. This is like taking the integral of sqrt(x)-sqrt(x-5). The size of the secondary function is input as a percentage of the first function size.

author: debnog

description.text:
1950s Style Test Tube Rack. Traditionally made of pine. Plausibly could be printed with wood filament. Referenced in the banned DIY science book: The Golden Book of Chemistry Experiments.
Shout Out: Thanks to Tibor Orsos for the nice rendering from the GrabCAD Community! :)
V3: Fixed an alignment issue. Added Grooves to make it buildable from actual wood. Work in Progress.

Version 2 is got two circles. One at top and one at bottom of guide. Basic guide upgrade. Ver 5 Has plenty of room for filament to move back and forth as printer moves in all directions. Also makes no sounds (clicking or rubbing from filament as it moves around. Add supports. Added Version 6 with filament filter add on.
I put filament in filter first then add filter sponge. I pushed sponge in with my scrapper. ver 6- shortened height 1/2 mm. I was told it was a little loose.It might be variation in metal when made by WANHAO. Mine fits perfect. Let me know if you need it bigger or smaller. remix jnk

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

50%

Notes: 40 mm/s speed

comments.text: On v5 I spent hours making it and it printed perfectly (with supports), but all it does it click, slap, etc. and that's when it's not sliding back and forth because it's extremely loose.  I may try v6 but it really seems that at least the filter free version, that the top hole is just a little too close to the frame, causing the filament on the bottom guide ring to constantly "slap" and rub the side on the frame, actually to the point where that friction is scratching the filament and I worry about it affecting the tolerances.
comments.author: CollinChaffin

comments.text: Which is the best way to print this, the one with filter.

comments.text: Added a v6 with filament filter add on. As Requested by  Quantumlight.

author: pavelbianca

title: Maximum Build Size Tool and Demo [Replicator 2(x)]

description.text:
This is the absolute largest thing a Replicator 2 or Replicator 2X is capable of building but also contains minimum materials.   
You can use this as a tool to double check weather a part can be replicated or to demonstrate the Replicator's build volume.  
The actual build volume as stated on the site is incorrect as can be seen by a test in the makerware software, so this is the max of it's true dimensions of 24L x 14W x 15.5H in cm. This object needs to be scaled, so just hit maximize size in the scale menu.   
Also, since every makerbot's build plate are all centered slightly differently (especially the 2X) you may notice the extruder print off of your plate. In that case just uncheck the uniform scaling icon and drag in the side that seems to be overhanging by the amount your observed, and then you  have your own custom print volume box.   
For printing use rafts and supports, I haven't tried without but I doubt it would go smoothly.

comments.text: Hey, is there any stringing/warping issues with those massive overhangs?

title: Filament Spool Wall Mount with Quick Snap Lock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: After hundreds of downloads over the last two yearsI decided to give the parts a new and smoother design. All new designs have the ending 'New' in the filename. SuperCone with better design to press the bearings in with less force. Lock Lever is user friendly rounded. Two versions for the Lock_Base: 'Wide' for more shrinking materials like ABS and usual printing quality, 'Narrow' if you print precisely and search for a klick feeling when close the lever. Two new 'SpoolBreak' parts to drag the filament spool a bit and keep the drag constantly. The 'Small' break touches only on the bearing and produces a little drag, the 'Big' rub the cone for a more significant effect. See pictures. All other parts are unchanged. Usually my Spool Bearing Railway http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1023865 is working very well, but for long hour (over night) prints I prefer to have a conventional wall mounted spool holder with very low friction. I searched for something and found this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:969358. First I printed these parts but unfortunately the level-basis broke away two times and the cone was not able to hold some of my Taulman spools. Anyway, thank's a lot to loco for all the inspiring to my solution. :-) My wall mount spool holder fits for two spool of any size I have seen so far. The cones have a 608 ball bearing and supports inner spool diameters from 15mm up to 60mm. Fast lock-levers with an inside M8 (or 5/16") thread allow locking AND tightening the cones by turning them like a bolt. But there is also a new genius auto-snap piece that locks automatically in place. Movements are possible by pitching it and the self-made spring inside locks it after releasing. Also this piece can be tightening additionally if needed. That means you can either print the M8 Auto Snap piece OR the 'classic' parts with M8 Lock Base and M8 Lock Lever. See instructions to build the Auto Snap with a paper-clip! A wall mount thing is also included, but you can - of course - use any other metal or wood support you like. If you enjoyed the thing please give a comment. Same if you have problems or questions, please. ADDITION:
Click-Fix option to handle loose filament spools is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1096249 Enjoy!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm - 0.3mm

Infill:

50% - 75%

Notes: I printed all in ABS. All walls 1.2mm. Speed ca. 50mm/sec. Auto Lock in 0.2mm layer height, Wall Mount in 0.3mm height, all other parts in 0.25mm height. Print times and details:
  • Cone: 0.25mm layer height, 50-75% infill: 1h00
  • Auto Snap: 0.20mm, 50%: 0h50
  • Wall Mount: 0.30mm, 75%: 2h30 flat, 5h00 upright (needed on my printer)
  • Lock Bases: 0.25mm, 75%: 0h30
  • Lock Lever: 0.25mm, 50-75%: 0h15
  • SpoolBreaks: 75%: 0h05

Instructions

  • I used a 40cm (new 60cm!) M8 threaded rod to have enough space for wider rolls.

  • Press one 608 roll bearing carefully into the every cone. I use a bench vise with plastic preserver (like this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1023770) to not damage anything.

  • Build the Auto Snap (see pictures below):
    a) You need a paper-clip to build the spring in the Auto Snap piece. Take a good quality one, others are to weak and not functioning well. Mine was 36-42mm long and the wire with a diameter of 1mm.
    b) Cut it to 26mm (1 inch) as on the pictures. Do not use your fine side-cutting pliers to not damage it, use a strong tool for that.
    c) Mount the wire with a needle-nosed pliers. You have to find the channel in 15° to strongly push it in the right position. Often you have to turn a little bit while pushing. At the end the wire should go in the right position and only is visible for 1-2mm in the inner diameter.

  • If the Auto Snap is not the right way for you, just print the classic Lock Lever. Screw together with a M3x16 countersunk head screw that will fit into the plastic.

Design Cone designed in SketchUp.
Auto Snap piece first designed as some prototypes to see if it works. Then the inlay (see attached pictures) designed in TinkerCad and imported to 123D Design to complete.
All other parts designed in TinkerCad.

remixed_from.author: thruit00
remixed_from.title: Active Cooling Fan Duct v2 for Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge / CTC

title: Extruder Fan Duct for Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge

description.text:
Extruder Fan Duct for Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge / CTC This is a remix of thing:537918 Thanks thruit00! FINAL UPDATE: I've submitted a few final changes to v3 and I'm also publishing the cleaned up source SketchUp file for you to mix and edit. I likely won't be making any other changes since these are lasting over a year before any noticeable sagging, etc. Goal:
I really like the Active Cooling Fan Duct v2 and used it for quite a while (about 600 hours) but it would slowly warp and sag at the tips after 100 hours or so in my machine. This was even worse in cases where the fan was off during the printing process and the temperature was high for certain materials. I found myself reprinting it over and over and covering it in multiple exotic heat blocking materials to no avail. I wanted to remake the business end of the duct to be farther away from the heater blocks and less prone to warp while still providing ample breeze to the sweet spots, and add illumination the extruder tips. Changes:
  • Original Author couldn't provide source cad files and I couldn't import the .stl's cleanly, so I basically had to remake the whole model using the original .stl as a guide. It's definitely not as curvy and may not actually move as much air. I have done no testing other than whetting my finger and holding it beneath the duct with a fan running and testing with prints. It works well for me.
  • Duct ends are farther away from tips and less prone to warpage
  • LED mount to illuminate deposition zone
  • The fillet around the inner hole on top of the mounting clip was removed (just my personal preference)
  • Miscellaneous minor adjustments were made to the shape to reduce unnecessary weight and improve print-ability.
    • Included is a version with and without a hole for the LED, and the mounting clips (you'll need two!). If you install the LED, just run the lead wires out around the motor where the motor wires come out as illustrated in the picture. For seriously fantastic information regarding compatibility, printing, and installation instructions; please refer to the original thing:537918. Happy Printing!
Installed in a Wanhao Duplicator 4S.

comments.text: Seems to have airflow restrictions so I cut back the one side I don't use 1/2 inch and glued the holes shut, then cut the side I do use and cut it back 1/2" with a jigsaw (only using single extruder), then tilted the fan in its mount so that the bottom is barely being held in place, allowing more air flow from the top of the fan.  I can put my hand behind the whole carriage and feel air moving now.  Prints the boat benchy extremely well now.
comments.author: mbrownn

comments.text: @mdbrownn:  That's nice that you were able to modify it for your needs.  Unfortunately, with my machine, the fan barely clears, and I cannot spare that space as I move the extruder off of the bed to a wipe tower that I have installed.  Also, regarding the circuit board as a print surface, that's nice that it works well for you.  I find that very thick high quality glass with a thin film of purple Elmers glue stick works well for me, and is very repeatable.  I would suggest this method, as it is very hard to find a PCB that doesn't warp with heat.  Ever hear of the Xbox and PS3 failures due to Ball Grid Array failure?  This was due to the system overheating and the connections loosing contact when the circuit board warped with the heat.

description.text:
I've got a non-standard round glass (165mm diameter) for headbed (220mm). So I had to design a kind of plastic spring to center and fix the glass. Springs printed in ABS and sanded for a lot, but still fairly slipery and can't stop the glass from spinning :( At last I stuck my glass to heatbed with small kapton stripes. UPD: ABS is quite slicky to stop the glass from slipping (rotating around vertical axis in my case).
I coated the spring friction surfaces with polyurethane glue. No more slipping, the glass is fixed enough for printing and still easy removable.

comments.text: Hi Anthony,
comments.author: Anthony

comments.text: How did you solve the problem, that the goPro creates unsharp pictures underwater? Did you change the lens protection on the case or did you use it as it was?
comments.author: elk

comments.text: Elk, I just used the standard lens on the 1080P setting.  The pictures I posted with this thing were taken by my wife using a SeaLife 10MP camera.  It auto corrects color for the different depths and colors of water.  The lake we were diving didn't have the best lighting and visibility conditions by any means but the camera did a pretty good job.  The GoPro camera did a pretty good job at taking video as well.  It's a little blurry around the edges but not bad.  I'll post some videos on YouTube sometime and at a link to it here.
comments.author: elk

comments.text: I have a goPro myself and I was not happy with the latest underwater-shots i made therefore I thought you maybe found a sollution for this issue. After a bit of research I found out, that there are different modifications available to get a propper, sharp image underwater (it is a problem of the domed lens cover of the case... you can either replace it by a flat one or buy/build an external flat glas/cover for the case). I thought you might be interessed in it... here you find one of the possible solutions: http://www.eyeofmine.com/gopro/underwater/index.htmlhttp://www.eyeofmine.com/gopro...

author: Feder205

description.text:
I really liked the looks of cswaim's "Simple iPad Stand", but lately we have been putting the iPad in a case for my daughter to use it. (We use a Beetle Defense case for our iPad, which I think is a 4th gen iPad, IIRC.) I widened the opening for the iPad by extending the front jaws by 8mm, and it works pretty well.
My printer uses 3mm filament which is basically 1/8", so I just cut off a section of filament and pounded it in with a hammer for the hinge pin. Works great, no glue needed because I didn't clean the hole out so it is pretty tight.
I think it would be nice if it had some tweaks to make the angles mate up with the iPad case better, but it works well as-is, at least for the case we have.

title: BT Home Hub 5 wall mount bracket

description.text:
A simple wall bracket for the BT Home Hub 5, which cannot be mounted to the wall. This design as it is requires the legs to be trimmed by about 7mm, easy enough to do. If you modified the blender file, you could remove this requirement by spacing everything away from the wall more.
Fits a 100mm screw hole pattern, but could be adjusted in the blend file.
The arms clip on perfectly, nice and strong but not too much. Printed up nice in black ABS.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20% Rect

Notes: Simple print.
Glue together Glue the sides onto the baseplate after a dry fit. I used Acetone on my ABS print. Make sure to keep things nice and square.

author: Ledrige

description.text:
The Creality CR-7/Freaks3d machine is kinda difficult to get the belts tight.
I didnt like the way the one sided acrylic holders sort of bent under belt tension.
There are a few other belt tensioning designs either too bulky or i could not get them to work properly.
I found a spring loaded adjuster gcode but could not find springs with enough tension,and I lost about 20mm print area.
Trying to learn freecad I decided to design my own.
This is my first practical design with freecad.
Ive printed different versions of these holders for about two weeks with no problems. I really liked these,they look like they are part of the machine.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

40%

Notes: The first versions I did almost solid @90% infill.
At 40% infill they are still strong enough to work properly
Printed as two parts to minimize support.

A bit of post printing is necessary due to the 90 degree overhang/support.
I just pushed it into an empty v-slot joint little by little until it fit snugly,scraped the slot with a hobby knife.

Tighten the belt with the bearings in but the without the bolt.
Then pry the bolt into the bearing,it should be just about the right belt tension.
Sometimes it takes an extra try,but the belt can be adjusted loose,and the idler bearings can be inserted mounted and after.

comments.text: Can you make another version where the bearing would align with the aluminum bracket?
